controllers.smc.core.sliding_surface¶

Source: src\controllers\smc\core\sliding_surface.py

Module Overview¶

Sliding Surface Calculations for SMC Controllers.

Provides unified sliding surface computation that can be shared across all SMC types. Implements both linear and nonlinear sliding surface formulations with proper mathematical foundations.

Mathematical Background:

  • Linear sliding surface: s = c₁e₁ + c₂e₂ + λ₁ė₁ + λ₂ė₂

  • Where e₁, e₂ are tracking errors and ė₁, ė₂ are error derivatives

  • Coefficients c₁, c₂, λ₁, λ₂ must be positive for stability (Hurwitz requirement)

Mathematical Foundation¶

Sliding Mode Control Theory¶

Sliding mode control forces system trajectories onto a sliding surface where desired dynamics are exhibited.

\[s(\vec{x}, t) = 0\]

Where \(s: \mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{R}_+ \to \mathbb{R}^m\) is the sliding surface function.

Linear Sliding Surface for DIP¶

For the double-inverted pendulum with state \(\vec{x} = [x, \dot{x}, \theta_1, \dot{\theta}_1, \theta_2, \dot{\theta}_2]^T\):

\[s = \lambda_1 \dot{\theta}_1 + c_1 \theta_1 + \lambda_2 \dot{\theta}_2 + c_2 \theta_2\]

Physical Interpretation:

  • \(\theta_1, \theta_2\): Angular errors (desired = 0 for stabilization)

  • \(\dot{\theta}_1, \dot{\theta}_2\): Angular velocity errors

  • \(c_1, c_2 > 0\): Position feedback gains

  • \(\lambda_1, \lambda_2 > 0\): Velocity feedback gains

Hurwitz Stability Criterion¶

For the sliding surface to ensure exponential convergence when \(s = 0\):

\[\dot{s} = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \lambda_i \ddot{\theta}_i + c_i \dot{\theta}_i = 0, \quad i = 1, 2\]

This gives characteristic polynomial:

\[p(r) = r + \frac{c_i}{\lambda_i}\]

Hurwitz criterion requires all roots to have negative real parts:

\[\frac{c_i}{\lambda_i} > 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad c_i, \lambda_i > 0\]

This ensures exponential convergence to zero:

\[\theta_i(t) = \theta_i(0) e^{-\frac{c_i}{\lambda_i} t}\]

Lyapunov Stability¶

Lyapunov function:

\[V(s) = \frac{1}{2} s^2\]

Sliding condition (Lyapunov stability):

\[\dot{V} = s \dot{s} < 0 \quad \text{for} \quad s \neq 0\]

This ensures trajectories are attracted to the sliding surface and remain there.

Reaching Condition¶

Finite-time reaching requires:

\[s \dot{s} \leq -\eta |s|, \quad \eta > 0\]

Reaching time bound:

\[t_{reach} \leq \frac{|s(0)|}{\eta}\]

Sliding Surface Design Guidelines¶

  1. Hurwitz requirement: All gains \(c_i, \lambda_i > 0\)

  2. Convergence rate: Larger \(c_i/\lambda_i\) → faster convergence

  3. Overshoot control: Smaller \(c_i/\lambda_i\) → less overshoot

  4. Typical range: \(c_i/\lambda_i \in [0.5, 5.0]\) rad/s

Higher-Order Sliding Surfaces¶

Super-Twisting (2nd order):

\[s = \sigma, \quad \dot{\sigma} = \lambda_1 \dot{\theta}_1 + c_1 \theta_1 + \lambda_2 \dot{\theta}_2 + c_2 \theta_2\]

Provides finite-time convergence and continuous control (no chattering).

Computational Complexity¶

  • Linear surface evaluation: \(O(n)\) multiply-adds

  • Surface derivative: \(O(n^2)\) if Jacobian needed

  • Memory: \(O(n)\) for gains and state

Architecture Diagram¶

graph TD A[State Vector x] --> B[Extract Errors: θ₁, θ₂, θ̇₁, θ̇₂] B --> C[Compute s = λ₁θ̇₁ + c₁θ₁ + λ₂θ̇₂ + c₂θ₂] C --> D{|s| < ε?} D -->|Yes| E[On Sliding Surface] D -->|No| F[Off Sliding Surface] E --> G[Sliding Mode Reached] F --> H[Reaching Phase] B --> I[Validate Gains: c₁, c₂, λ₁, λ₂ > 0] I -->|Invalid| J[Raise ValueError] I -->|Valid| C style C fill:#9cf style E fill:#9f9 style F fill:#ff9 style J fill:#f99

Usage Examples¶

Example 1: Basic Linear Sliding Surface¶

from src.controllers.smc.core.sliding_surface import LinearSlidingSurface
import numpy as np

# Define gains (c1, c2, λ1, λ2)
gains = [10.0, 8.0, 15.0, 12.0]
surface = LinearSlidingSurface(gains)

# Compute surface value for state
state = np.array([0.1, 0.0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.02, 0.05])  # [x, ẋ, θ₁, θ̇₁, θ₂, θ̇₂]
s = surface.compute(state)
print(f"Sliding surface value: {s:.4f}")

Example 2: Surface Derivative Computation¶

# Compute surface derivative ds/dt
state_dot = np.array([0.0, 0.0, 0.1, -0.5, 0.05, -0.3])
s_dot = surface.compute_derivative(state, state_dot)
print(f"Surface derivative: {s_dot:.4f}")

# Check sliding condition
if abs(s) < 0.01 and s * s_dot < 0:
    print("Sliding mode reached and maintained")

Example 3: Gain Validation¶

from src.controllers.smc.core.sliding_surface import validate_sliding_surface_gains

# Valid gains (all positive)
gains_valid = [10.0, 8.0, 15.0, 12.0]
is_valid = validate_sliding_surface_gains(gains_valid)
print(f"Valid gains: {is_valid}")  # True

# Invalid gains (c2 negative)
gains_invalid = [10.0, -8.0, 15.0, 12.0]
try:
    surface_bad = LinearSlidingSurface(gains_invalid)
except ValueError as e:
    print(f"Validation error: {e}")

Example 4: Frequency Analysis¶

# example-metadata:
# runnable: false

# Compute characteristic frequencies
c1, c2, lambda1, lambda2 = gains
omega_n1 = np.sqrt(c1 / lambda1)  # rad/s
omega_n2 = np.sqrt(c2 / lambda2)  # rad/s

print(f"Natural frequency 1: {omega_n1:.2f} rad/s")
print(f"Natural frequency 2: {omega_n2:.2f} rad/s")

# Check Nyquist criterion (sampling frequency 100 Hz)
omega_s = 2 * np.pi * 100  # rad/s
if omega_n1 < omega_s / 5 and omega_n2 < omega_s / 5:
    print("Frequencies safe for 100 Hz sampling")

Example 5: Higher-Order Surface (Super-Twisting)¶

from src.controllers.smc.core.sliding_surface import HigherOrderSlidingSurface

# Define 6 gains for 2nd order surface
gains_ho = [25.0, 10.0, 15.0, 12.0, 20.0, 15.0]
surface_ho = HigherOrderSlidingSurface(gains_ho)

# Compute surface and its derivative
s_ho = surface_ho.compute(state)
s_dot_ho = surface_ho.compute_derivative(state, state_dot)

print(f"Higher-order surface: s={s_ho:.4f}, ṡ={s_dot_ho:.4f}")

Complete Source Code¶

  1#======================================================================================\\\
  2#==================== src/controllers/smc/core/sliding_surface.py =====================\\\
  3#======================================================================================\\\
  4
  5"""
  6Sliding Surface Calculations for SMC Controllers.
  7
  8Provides unified sliding surface computation that can be shared across all SMC types.
  9Implements both linear and nonlinear sliding surface formulations with proper
 10mathematical foundations.
 11
 12Mathematical Background:
 13- Linear sliding surface: s = c₁e₁ + c₂e₂ + λ₁ė₁ + λ₂ė₂
 14- Where e₁, e₂ are tracking errors and ė₁, ė₂ are error derivatives
 15- Coefficients c₁, c₂, λ₁, λ₂ must be positive for stability (Hurwitz requirement)
 16"""
 17
 18from typing import List, Union
 19import numpy as np
 20from abc import ABC, abstractmethod
 21
 22
 23class SlidingSurface(ABC):
 24    """Abstract base class for sliding surface calculations."""
 25
 26    def __init__(self, gains: Union[List[float], np.ndarray]):
 27        self.gains = np.asarray(gains, dtype=float)
 28        self._validate_gains()
 29
 30    @abstractmethod
 31    def _validate_gains(self) -> None:
 32        """Validate gains for this specific sliding surface type."""
 33        pass
 34
 35    @abstractmethod
 36    def compute(self, state: np.ndarray) -> float:
 37        """Compute sliding surface value for given state."""
 38        pass
 39
 40    @abstractmethod
 41    def compute_derivative(self, state: np.ndarray, state_dot: np.ndarray) -> float:
 42        """Compute sliding surface derivative ds/dt."""
 43        pass
 44
 45
 46class LinearSlidingSurface(SlidingSurface):
 47    """
 48    Linear sliding surface for conventional SMC.
 49
 50    Implements: s = λ₁ė₁ + c₁e₁ + λ₂ė₂ + c₂e₂
 51
 52    For double-inverted pendulum:
 53    - e₁ = θ₁ (joint 1 angle error)
 54    - e₂ = θ₂ (joint 2 angle error)
 55    - ė₁ = θ̇₁ (joint 1 velocity error)
 56    - ė₂ = θ̇₂ (joint 2 velocity error)
 57    """
 58
 59    def __init__(self, gains: Union[List[float], np.ndarray]):
 60        """
 61        Initialize linear sliding surface.
 62
 63        Args:
 64            gains: [k1, k2, lam1, lam2] where:
 65                   k1, k2 = position gains (must be > 0)
 66                   lam1, lam2 = velocity gains (must be > 0)
 67        """
 68        super().__init__(gains)
 69
 70        if len(self.gains) < 4:
 71            raise ValueError("Linear sliding surface requires at least 4 gains [k1, k2, lam1, lam2]")
 72
 73        self.k1 = self.gains[0]      # Joint 1 position gain
 74        self.k2 = self.gains[1]      # Joint 2 position gain
 75        self.lam1 = self.gains[2]    # Joint 1 velocity gain
 76        self.lam2 = self.gains[3]    # Joint 2 velocity gain
 77
 78    def _validate_gains(self) -> None:
 79        """Validate that surface gains satisfy stability requirements."""
 80        # Check for finite values
 81        if not np.all(np.isfinite(self.gains)):
 82            invalid_indices = np.where(~np.isfinite(self.gains))[0]
 83            raise ValueError(f"Sliding surface gains contain NaN or infinite values at indices: {invalid_indices}")
 84
 85        if len(self.gains) >= 4:
 86            # First 4 gains must be positive for Hurwitz stability
 87            if any(g <= 0 for g in self.gains[:4]):
 88                raise ValueError(
 89                    "Sliding surface gains [k1, k2, lam1, lam2] must be positive for stability"
 90                )
 91
 92            # Check for very small gains that might cause numerical issues
 93            if any(g < 1e-12 for g in self.gains[:4]):
 94                raise ValueError(
 95                    "Sliding surface gains are too small (minimum: 1e-12) which may cause numerical instability"
 96                )
 97
 98    def compute(self, state: np.ndarray) -> float:
 99        """
100        Compute linear sliding surface value.
101
102        Args:
103            state: [x, x_dot, theta1, theta1_dot, theta2, theta2_dot]
104
105        Returns:
106            Sliding surface value: s = lam1*theta1_dot + k1*theta1 + lam2*theta2_dot + k2*theta2
107        """
108        if len(state) < 6:
109            raise ValueError("State must have at least 6 elements for double-inverted pendulum")
110
111        # Validate state input
112        if not np.all(np.isfinite(state)):
113            # Replace non-finite values with zeros for safe computation
114            state = np.where(np.isfinite(state), state, 0.0)
115
116        # Extract joint angles and velocities (reference is upright: theta=0)
117        theta1 = state[2]      # Joint 1 angle error
118        theta1_dot = state[3]  # Joint 1 velocity error
119        theta2 = state[4]      # Joint 2 angle error
120        theta2_dot = state[5]  # Joint 2 velocity error
121
122        # Linear sliding surface: s = λ₁ė₁ + c₁e₁ + λ₂ė₂ + c₂e₂
123        s = (self.lam1 * theta1_dot + self.k1 * theta1 +
124             self.lam2 * theta2_dot + self.k2 * theta2)
125
126        # Ensure finite result
127        if not np.isfinite(s):
128            return 0.0  # Safe fallback for numerical issues
129
130        return float(s)
131
132    def compute_surface(self, state: np.ndarray) -> float:
133        """
134        Compatibility method for test interface - alias for compute().
135
136        Args:
137            state: State vector
138
139        Returns:
140            Sliding surface value
141        """
142        return self.compute(state)
143
144    def compute_derivative(self, state: np.ndarray, state_dot: np.ndarray) -> float:
145        """
146        Compute sliding surface derivative ds/dt.
147
148        Args:
149            state: Current state vector
150            state_dot: State derivative vector
151
152        Returns:
153            Surface derivative: ṡ = λ₁θ̈₁ + c₁θ̇₁ + λ₂θ̈₂ + c₂θ̇₂
154        """
155        if len(state_dot) < 6:
156            raise ValueError("State derivative must have at least 6 elements")
157
158        # Extract joint accelerations and velocities
159        theta1_dot = state[3]     # Joint 1 velocity
160        theta1_ddot = state_dot[3] # Joint 1 acceleration
161        theta2_dot = state[5]     # Joint 2 velocity
162        theta2_ddot = state_dot[5] # Joint 2 acceleration
163
164        # Surface derivative
165        s_dot = (self.lam1 * theta1_ddot + self.k1 * theta1_dot +
166                 self.lam2 * theta2_ddot + self.k2 * theta2_dot)
167
168        return float(s_dot)
169
170    def get_coefficients(self) -> dict:
171        """Return surface coefficients for analysis."""
172        return {
173            'k1': self.k1,
174            'k2': self.k2,
175            'lambda1': self.lam1,
176            'lambda2': self.lam2
177        }
178
179
180class HigherOrderSlidingSurface(SlidingSurface):
181    """
182    Higher-order sliding surface for Super-Twisting and advanced SMC.
183
184    Implements surfaces that include higher-order derivatives for
185    finite-time convergence and better disturbance rejection.
186    """
187
188    def __init__(self, gains: Union[List[float], np.ndarray], order: int = 2):
189        """
190        Initialize higher-order sliding surface.
191
192        Args:
193            gains: Gain vector for higher-order surface
194            order: Surface order (1=classical, 2=super-twisting, etc.)
195        """
196        super().__init__(gains)
197        self.order = order
198
199        if order < 1:
200            raise ValueError("Surface order must be >= 1")
201
202        expected_gains = 2 * order  # 2 gains per order for 2-DOF system
203        if len(self.gains) < expected_gains:
204            raise ValueError(f"Order {order} surface requires at least {expected_gains} gains")
205
206    def _validate_gains(self) -> None:
207        """Validate gains for higher-order stability."""
208        # For higher-order surfaces, gain positivity requirements are more complex
209        # Basic requirement: all gains should be positive
210        if any(g <= 0 for g in self.gains):
211            raise ValueError("All gains must be positive for higher-order sliding surface")
212
213    def compute(self, state: np.ndarray) -> float:
214        """Compute higher-order sliding surface (simplified implementation)."""
215        # This would implement more complex surface formulations
216        # For now, fall back to linear surface computation
217        if len(self.gains) >= 4:
218            linear_surface = LinearSlidingSurface(self.gains[:4])
219            return linear_surface.compute(state)
220        return 0.0
221
222    def compute_derivative(self, state: np.ndarray, state_dot: np.ndarray) -> float:
223        """Compute higher-order surface derivative."""
224        # Simplified implementation
225        if len(self.gains) >= 4:
226            linear_surface = LinearSlidingSurface(self.gains[:4])
227            return linear_surface.compute_derivative(state, state_dot)
228        return 0.0
229
230
231def create_sliding_surface(surface_type: str, gains: Union[List[float], np.ndarray]) -> SlidingSurface:
232    """
233    Factory function for creating sliding surfaces.
234
235    Args:
236        surface_type: "linear" or "higher_order"
237        gains: Gain vector
238
239    Returns:
240        Appropriate sliding surface instance
241    """
242    if surface_type.lower() == "linear":
243        return LinearSlidingSurface(gains)
244    elif surface_type.lower() in ("higher_order", "higher-order"):
245        return HigherOrderSlidingSurface(gains)
246    else:
247        raise ValueError(f"Unknown surface type: {surface_type}")

Classes¶

SlidingSurface¶

Inherits from: ABC

Abstract base class for sliding surface calculations.

Source Code¶

 1class SlidingSurface(ABC):
 2    """Abstract base class for sliding surface calculations."""
 3
 4    def __init__(self, gains: Union[List[float], np.ndarray]):
 5        self.gains = np.asarray(gains, dtype=float)
 6        self._validate_gains()
 7
 8    @abstractmethod
 9    def _validate_gains(self) -> None:
10        """Validate gains for this specific sliding surface type."""
11        pass
12
13    @abstractmethod
14    def compute(self, state: np.ndarray) -> float:
15        """Compute sliding surface value for given state."""
16        pass
17
18    @abstractmethod
19    def compute_derivative(self, state: np.ndarray, state_dot: np.ndarray) -> float:
20        """Compute sliding surface derivative ds/dt."""
21        pass

LinearSlidingSurface¶

Inherits from: SlidingSurface

Linear sliding surface for conventional SMC.

Implements: s = λ₁ė₁ + c₁e₁ + λ₂ė₂ + c₂e₂

For double-inverted pendulum:

  • e₁ = θ₁ (joint 1 angle error)

  • e₂ = θ₂ (joint 2 angle error)

  • ė₁ = θ̇₁ (joint 1 velocity error)

  • ė₂ = θ̇₂ (joint 2 velocity error)

Source Code¶

  1class LinearSlidingSurface(SlidingSurface):
  2    """
  3    Linear sliding surface for conventional SMC.
  4
  5    Implements: s = λ₁ė₁ + c₁e₁ + λ₂ė₂ + c₂e₂
  6
  7    For double-inverted pendulum:
  8    - e₁ = θ₁ (joint 1 angle error)
  9    - e₂ = θ₂ (joint 2 angle error)
 10    - ė₁ = θ̇₁ (joint 1 velocity error)
 11    - ė₂ = θ̇₂ (joint 2 velocity error)
 12    """
 13
 14    def __init__(self, gains: Union[List[float], np.ndarray]):
 15        """
 16        Initialize linear sliding surface.
 17
 18        Args:
 19            gains: [k1, k2, lam1, lam2] where:
 20                   k1, k2 = position gains (must be > 0)
 21                   lam1, lam2 = velocity gains (must be > 0)
 22        """
 23        super().__init__(gains)
 24
 25        if len(self.gains) < 4:
 26            raise ValueError("Linear sliding surface requires at least 4 gains [k1, k2, lam1, lam2]")
 27
 28        self.k1 = self.gains[0]      # Joint 1 position gain
 29        self.k2 = self.gains[1]      # Joint 2 position gain
 30        self.lam1 = self.gains[2]    # Joint 1 velocity gain
 31        self.lam2 = self.gains[3]    # Joint 2 velocity gain
 32
 33    def _validate_gains(self) -> None:
 34        """Validate that surface gains satisfy stability requirements."""
 35        # Check for finite values
 36        if not np.all(np.isfinite(self.gains)):
 37            invalid_indices = np.where(~np.isfinite(self.gains))[0]
 38            raise ValueError(f"Sliding surface gains contain NaN or infinite values at indices: {invalid_indices}")
 39
 40        if len(self.gains) >= 4:
 41            # First 4 gains must be positive for Hurwitz stability
 42            if any(g <= 0 for g in self.gains[:4]):
 43                raise ValueError(
 44                    "Sliding surface gains [k1, k2, lam1, lam2] must be positive for stability"
 45                )
 46
 47            # Check for very small gains that might cause numerical issues
 48            if any(g < 1e-12 for g in self.gains[:4]):
 49                raise ValueError(
 50                    "Sliding surface gains are too small (minimum: 1e-12) which may cause numerical instability"
 51                )
 52
 53    def compute(self, state: np.ndarray) -> float:
 54        """
 55        Compute linear sliding surface value.
 56
 57        Args:
 58            state: [x, x_dot, theta1, theta1_dot, theta2, theta2_dot]
 59
 60        Returns:
 61            Sliding surface value: s = lam1*theta1_dot + k1*theta1 + lam2*theta2_dot + k2*theta2
 62        """
 63        if len(state) < 6:
 64            raise ValueError("State must have at least 6 elements for double-inverted pendulum")
 65
 66        # Validate state input
 67        if not np.all(np.isfinite(state)):
 68            # Replace non-finite values with zeros for safe computation
 69            state = np.where(np.isfinite(state), state, 0.0)
 70
 71        # Extract joint angles and velocities (reference is upright: theta=0)
 72        theta1 = state[2]      # Joint 1 angle error
 73        theta1_dot = state[3]  # Joint 1 velocity error
 74        theta2 = state[4]      # Joint 2 angle error
 75        theta2_dot = state[5]  # Joint 2 velocity error
 76
 77        # Linear sliding surface: s = λ₁ė₁ + c₁e₁ + λ₂ė₂ + c₂e₂
 78        s = (self.lam1 * theta1_dot + self.k1 * theta1 +
 79             self.lam2 * theta2_dot + self.k2 * theta2)
 80
 81        # Ensure finite result
 82        if not np.isfinite(s):
 83            return 0.0  # Safe fallback for numerical issues
 84
 85        return float(s)
 86
 87    def compute_surface(self, state: np.ndarray) -> float:
 88        """
 89        Compatibility method for test interface - alias for compute().
 90
 91        Args:
 92            state: State vector
 93
 94        Returns:
 95            Sliding surface value
 96        """
 97        return self.compute(state)
 98
 99    def compute_derivative(self, state: np.ndarray, state_dot: np.ndarray) -> float:
100        """
101        Compute sliding surface derivative ds/dt.
102
103        Args:
104            state: Current state vector
105            state_dot: State derivative vector
106
107        Returns:
108            Surface derivative: ṡ = λ₁θ̈₁ + c₁θ̇₁ + λ₂θ̈₂ + c₂θ̇₂
109        """
110        if len(state_dot) < 6:
111            raise ValueError("State derivative must have at least 6 elements")
112
113        # Extract joint accelerations and velocities
114        theta1_dot = state[3]     # Joint 1 velocity
115        theta1_ddot = state_dot[3] # Joint 1 acceleration
116        theta2_dot = state[5]     # Joint 2 velocity
117        theta2_ddot = state_dot[5] # Joint 2 acceleration
118
119        # Surface derivative
120        s_dot = (self.lam1 * theta1_ddot + self.k1 * theta1_dot +
121                 self.lam2 * theta2_ddot + self.k2 * theta2_dot)
122
123        return float(s_dot)
124
125    def get_coefficients(self) -> dict:
126        """Return surface coefficients for analysis."""
127        return {
128            'k1': self.k1,
129            'k2': self.k2,
130            'lambda1': self.lam1,
131            'lambda2': self.lam2
132        }

HigherOrderSlidingSurface¶

Inherits from: SlidingSurface

Higher-order sliding surface for Super-Twisting and advanced SMC.

Implements surfaces that include higher-order derivatives for finite-time convergence and better disturbance rejection.

Source Code¶

 1class HigherOrderSlidingSurface(SlidingSurface):
 2    """
 3    Higher-order sliding surface for Super-Twisting and advanced SMC.
 4
 5    Implements surfaces that include higher-order derivatives for
 6    finite-time convergence and better disturbance rejection.
 7    """
 8
 9    def __init__(self, gains: Union[List[float], np.ndarray], order: int = 2):
10        """
11        Initialize higher-order sliding surface.
12
13        Args:
14            gains: Gain vector for higher-order surface
15            order: Surface order (1=classical, 2=super-twisting, etc.)
16        """
17        super().__init__(gains)
18        self.order = order
19
20        if order < 1:
21            raise ValueError("Surface order must be >= 1")
22
23        expected_gains = 2 * order  # 2 gains per order for 2-DOF system
24        if len(self.gains) < expected_gains:
25            raise ValueError(f"Order {order} surface requires at least {expected_gains} gains")
26
27    def _validate_gains(self) -> None:
28        """Validate gains for higher-order stability."""
29        # For higher-order surfaces, gain positivity requirements are more complex
30        # Basic requirement: all gains should be positive
31        if any(g <= 0 for g in self.gains):
32            raise ValueError("All gains must be positive for higher-order sliding surface")
33
34    def compute(self, state: np.ndarray) -> float:
35        """Compute higher-order sliding surface (simplified implementation)."""
36        # This would implement more complex surface formulations
37        # For now, fall back to linear surface computation
38        if len(self.gains) >= 4:
39            linear_surface = LinearSlidingSurface(self.gains[:4])
40            return linear_surface.compute(state)
41        return 0.0
42
43    def compute_derivative(self, state: np.ndarray, state_dot: np.ndarray) -> float:
44        """Compute higher-order surface derivative."""
45        # Simplified implementation
46        if len(self.gains) >= 4:
47            linear_surface = LinearSlidingSurface(self.gains[:4])
48            return linear_surface.compute_derivative(state, state_dot)
49        return 0.0

Functions¶

create_sliding_surface(surface_type, gains)¶

Factory function for creating sliding surfaces.

Args: surface_type: “linear” or “higher_order” gains: Gain vector

Returns: Appropriate sliding surface instance

Source Code¶

 1def create_sliding_surface(surface_type: str, gains: Union[List[float], np.ndarray]) -> SlidingSurface:
 2    """
 3    Factory function for creating sliding surfaces.
 4
 5    Args:
 6        surface_type: "linear" or "higher_order"
 7        gains: Gain vector
 8
 9    Returns:
10        Appropriate sliding surface instance
11    """
12    if surface_type.lower() == "linear":
13        return LinearSlidingSurface(gains)
14    elif surface_type.lower() in ("higher_order", "higher-order"):
15        return HigherOrderSlidingSurface(gains)
16    else:
17        raise ValueError(f"Unknown surface type: {surface_type}")
